newsitem.title: INDIA: Britain helps pay for India polio vaccinations.
newsitem.headline: Britain helps pay for India polio vaccinations.

text.p: Britain pledged 47.5 million stg ($76 million) to India on Tuesday to help pay for an immunisation programme aimed at wiping out the crippling childhood disease of polio by 2000.

The British high commission (embassy) said in a statement that the visiting minister at the British Foreign Office responsible for South Asia, Liam Fox, witnessed officials from both countries sign an agreement in the Indian capital.
It was the largest amount that Britain's Overseas Development Administration had ever spent on an immunisation programme, the statement said.

India's three-year immunisation programme which started last December will cost around 139 million stg ($222 million), it said. Last year, Britain contributed 3.9 million stg ($6.2 million) to the scheme.
In 1995, 2,993 cases of polio were reported in India and 2,836 in the rest of the world, according to the World Health Organisation.
More than 80 million Indian children are expected to receive polio vaccination drops during the second annual round of immunisations scheduled for December, organisers said.
